awd_titl_txt: Wildfire Impacts on Air Quality and Nighttime Brown Carbon Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is part of a larger field campaign, the Western Wildfire Experiment for Cloud Chemistry, Aerosol Absorption and Nitrogen (WE-CAN), designed to characterize the emissions and evolution of western U.S. wildfire plumes.  The larger field campaign consists of an aircraft study based out of Boise ID focused on scientific questions related to fixed nitrogen, absorbing aerosols, cloud activation and chemistry in wildfire plumes.  This project is focused on ground-based measurements, in conjunction with the aircraft flights, to assess wildfire emissions of non-methane organic gases and to evaluate the optical properties of aerosols emitted by wildfires.  Results from this effort will provide data and information for more accurately modeling biomass burning emissions to the atmosphere and for potentially reducing exposures to harmful pollutants that result from wildfires.

This ground-based effort will be focused mainly on the nearby impacts of smoke chemistry in rural valleys near Boise both night and day.  The project includes a 6-week ground-based field deployment during the summertime in 2018.  Comprehensive air quality and atmospheric chemistry data will be collected for CO2, CO, NOx, NH3, VOCs, oxidants, PM, tracers, O3, NO3, IVOC, SVOC, black carbon (BC), and brown carbon (BrC).  In addition to supplementing the aircraft data, this data will be used to calculate smoldering/flaming ratios and emission factors for nighttime open burning.  There are also plans to explore, and quantify to the degree possible, the secondary source of BrC in nighttime aging of smoke. The data collected in this research will be used to improve the representation of nighttime smoke emissions, and especially that of BrC, for fire modeling. 

The NSF-funded WE-CAN field campaign is part of a more comprehensive team effort that is co-funded by NOAA (the NOAA project is named FIREX) and NASA (the NASA project is named FIREChem).  The NSF campaign will take place in the summer of 2018 and the NOAA and NASA campaigns are planned for the summer of 2019.

Award 1748266 Project Outcomes

Fires are one of the three main sources of emissions to the atmosphere along with vegetation and human activities. The amount of fuel burned at any location varies greatly in time due to many anthropogenic influences and natural variation in weather, etc. The emissions from fires include 1000's of compounds in the gas, liquid, or solid phase and the mixture of these chemicals can be very different fire to fire. The emissions also evolve in the atmosphere in complex and variable ways depending on weather, altitude, etc. In addition, it is difficult to measure the pollutants without specialized instruments often invented only in the last 5-10 years. Thus, the impacts of fires on atmospheric chemistry, radiative forcing, air quality, visibility, the tourism-based economy, and the residential sector are immense but they can be hard to predict for scientists, meteorologists, air quality specialists, and land managers who are interested in using controlled fire to reduce the impact of uncontrolled wildfires without harming air quality. During 2016-2019 a group of leading atmospheric scientists including Yokelson executed a series of large-scale experiments that collected data from multiple satellites, aircraft, ground-based stations, mobile labs, and over 100 experts in advanced measurements and modeling, fuel characteristics, meteorology, etc.  Yokelson was a key contributor to the planning, coordination, and training of other PIs and the pilots starting with a meeting he set up for the other PIs/pilots to introduce them to how airspace around fires is managed and what the most effective sampling strategies are. The NSF support also allowed him to make important contributions to the science with new measurements of 1) how the type and condition of the vegetation burning affects the chemistry of the emissions, 2) the production of ozone and other hazardous air pollutants in both fresh smoke and in post-emission chemistry, 3) how the optical properties of the smoke evolve downwind, which impacts the secondary chemistry of the gases, 4) how smoke interacts with pollutants from “non-fire” sources such as urban areas, and 5) how the size and mass of smoke particles reacts to changes in ambient temperature and smoke concentration in both the upper and lower atmosphere. After the series of experiments was complete and numerous useful results were published by team members, Yokelson co-organized a workshop with NSF support where the experts gathered to discuss the results and how to take full advantage of the linkages between studies, implement measures to share the advances with other scientists and the public, and plan the next fire research priorities for the coming years. Another outcome of the work was that many young scientists received the training that will enable them to continue our nations stellar record of research accomplishments into the future.
